title: Tokyo Guidelines 2018 for Acute Cholecystitis
description: Provides diagnostic criteria and severity grading for acute cholecystitis according to TG18 (Tokyo Guidelines 2018).

parameters.name: murphys_sign
parameters.description: Murphy's sign - Cessation of breathing during deep palpation of right upper quadrant

parameters.name: ruq_pain
parameters.description: Right upper abdominal quadrant mass, pain, or tenderness

parameters.name: imaging_findings
parameters.description: Imaging findings characteristic of acute cholecystitis (e.g. pericholecystic fluid, gallstones/debris)

parameters.name: cardiovascular_dysfunction
parameters.description: Cardiovascular dysfunction - Hypotension requiring treatment with dopamine ≥5 μg/kg per min or any dose of norepinephrine

parameters.name: neurological_dysfunction
parameters.description: Neurological dysfunction - Decreased level of consciousness

parameters.name: renal_dysfunction
parameters.description: Renal dysfunction - Oliguria or creatinine >2.0 mg/dL

parameters.name: palpable_mass
parameters.description: Palpable tender mass in the right upper abdominal quadrant

parameters.name: marked_inflammation
parameters.description: Marked local inflammation (gangrenous cholecystitis, pericholecystic abscess, hepatic abscess, biliary peritonitis, emphysematous cholecystitis)

ranges.interpretation: Does not meet diagnostic criteria for acute cholecystitis. Consider other diagnoses.
Meets diagnostic criteria for suspected acute cholecystitis. Further evaluation recommended.
Meets diagnostic criteria for definite acute cholecystitis. Proceed with severity grading.
Mild acute cholecystitis without organ dysfunction. 1.1% 30-day mortality. Early laparoscopic cholecystectomy recommended.
Moderate acute cholecystitis with local inflammation. 5.4% 30-day mortality. Immediate supportive care, antibiotics, and urgent cholecystectomy.
Severe acute cholecystitis with organ dysfunction. 18.8% 30-day mortality. ICU admission, organ support, emergent drainage or cholecystectomy.

references: Yokoe M, Hata J, Takada T, Strasberg SM, Asbun HJ, Wakabayashi G, et al. Tokyo Guidelines 2018: diagnostic criteria and severity grading of acute cholecystitis (with videos). J Hepatobiliary Pancreat Sci. 2018 Jan;25(1):41-54. doi: 10.1002/jhbp.515.

Takada T, Strasberg SM, Solomkin JS, Pitt HA, Gomi H, Yoshida M, et al. TG13: Updated Tokyo Guidelines for the management of acute cholangitis and cholecystitis. J Hepatobiliary Pancreat Sci. 2013 Jan;20(1):1-7. doi: 10.1007/s00534-012-0566-y.

Gomi H, Solomkin JS, Schlossberg D, Okamoto K, Takada T, Strasberg SM, et al. Tokyo Guidelines 2018: antimicrobial therapy for acute cholangitis and cholecystitis. J Hepatobiliary Pancreat Sci. 2018 Jan;25(1):3-16. doi: 10.1002/jhbp.518.
formula: Diagnostic: ≥1 item from Part A + ≥1 item from Part B (suspected) or Part A + Part B + Part C (definite). Severity: Grade III if any organ dysfunction, Grade II if any moderate criteria, Grade I if neither.
notes: TG18 diagnostic criteria remain unchanged from TG13
Suspected diagnosis: Part A + Part B
Definite diagnosis: Part A + Part B + Part C
Grade III criteria supersede Grade II criteria
Early laparoscopic cholecystectomy is recommended for all grades if patient can tolerate surgery
